title: RS21824
content: During the debates over the 1998 HEA amendments, campus crimes, particularly drug-related incidents, were a major concern for Congress. Representative Souder highlighted the increasing number of drug and alcohol-related incidents on college campuses, calling it an epidemic. As a response, Congress added a provision to P.L. 105-244, eliminating financial aid eligibility for students convicted of drug-related crimes. The legislation under P.L. 105-244 specifies that students convicted of drug-related crimes are ineligible for federal student assistance under Title IV of the HEA. Ineligibility duration depends on the offense type, recency, and prior convictions. Indefinite ineligibility occurs with multiple convictions. Reinstatement requires completion of a drug rehab program or record expungement. Students convicted of drug-related crimes are ineligible for federal student assistance under Title IV of the HEA. The ineligibility period varies based on the offense type and number of prior convictions. Reinstatement requires completion of a drug rehab program or record expungement. According to program regulations, students convicted of drug-related crimes may be eligible for federal financial assistance if they complete a drug rehabilitation program. The program must meet specific requirements to qualify for reinstatement of eligibility. Students convicted of drug-related crimes may be eligible for federal financial assistance if they complete a drug rehabilitation program that meets specific requirements. The program must be administered by a licensed insurance company, hospital, health clinic, or medical doctor, and include at least two unannounced drug tests. Participation in the program reduces the ineligibility period for federal financial aid. Upon completion, the student self-certifies their completion of the program. Since the adoption of the provision, over 180,000 students have been denied federal financial aid or faced delays. California and Texas have seen a high number of students declared ineligible. The Deficit Reduction Act of 2005 was enacted to address confusion and contention surrounding the provision. The Deficit Reduction Act of 2005 (DRA) amended the provision regarding drug convictions and federal student aid eligibility. It specified that only convictions occurring while a student is enrolled in postsecondary education and receiving Title IV aid would disqualify them. The period of ineligibility for drug convictions still depends on the type of conviction, recency, and prior convictions. Legislative proposals are being considered to modify this provision in the upcoming reauthorization of Title IV of the Higher Education Act. During the upcoming reauthorization of Title IV of the HEA, there are legislative proposals to modify the drug conviction provision. Issues such as implementation, penalties, and who should be penalized are being discussed. Policymakers are concerned about the increasing drug-related crimes on college campuses. Many policymakers are concerned about the rise in drug-related crimes on college campuses, leading to discussions about modifying the provision for eligibility of financial aid for students convicted of drug crimes. Critics argue that singling out drugs is unfair, while supporters believe focusing on drug crimes is justified due to their prevalence on campuses. The implications of limiting financial aid eligibility for drug convictions will be considered during reauthorization. During reauthorization, the consideration of drug-related crimes for eligibility of financial aid may lead to debates on distinguishing between misdemeanor and felony convictions. The current provision results in loss of eligibility for all convictions, regardless of jail time served. Different ineligibility periods for selling versus possession of controlled substances acknowledge a difference between users and sellers. Congress may also discuss the impact of felony versus misdemeanor drug convictions on student aid eligibility.
